awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Rivers and the carbon cycle: a mechanistic basis for dissolved organic carbon removal
awd_abstract_narration:
Streams and rivers are important for the removal of organic matter transported from land as water moves across landscapes.  Many questions remain about how organic matter is removed from freshwaters.  A key challenge is that not all organic matter is the same.  Organic matter dissolved in freshwaters is made up of many different compounds. These compounds range in age, source, and chemical composition, all of which can influence how fast they are processed.  To overcome this challenge, researchers will collect real-time sensor data and design field-scale experiments to measure how fast organic matter is removed by streams. The project aims to test hypotheses about what processes control the removal of different types of organic matter from streams and rivers.  This is important because organic matter provides energy that supports food webs, and can pollute downstream ecosystems. Organic matter processing can also determine rates of greenhouse emissions from streams and rivers to the atmosphere. This research will also provide valuable opportunities for high school teachers to engage in investigations that will enhance their ability to meet Next-Generation Science standards.

What processes drive organic carbon removal in streams, and how does organic carbon removal regulate the degree to which running waters are biological reactors versus exporters of organic carbon?  These are key unresolved questions in carbon cycle research.  This project will develop a proof-of-concept approach to test the hypothesis that non-additive effects of mixed organic matter sources (i.e. priming) control organic carbon removal in streams.  Data products will include estimates of organic carbon turnover distance derived from ecosystem metabolism and stream chemistry, as well as empirical measures of organic carbon removal from ecosystem-level experiments that use single-source and mixed organic carbon additions.  Project data and computer source codes will be shared openly via HydroShare and GitHub, respectively.  The research will be conducted at Flathead Lake Biological Station and the researchers will partner with the Station?s recently funded SensorSpace, a community facility for construction and testing of novel environmental sensors, as well as a test bed for integrating sensor-based data into Next-Generation Science curricula.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to understand how dissolved organic carbon (DOC), a food source for stream microbes, is metabolized and respired as carbon dioxide (CO2) in streams and rivers. Inland waterways are often sources of atmospheric CO2, and our work assessed the mechanisms that control DOC fluxes and fate, including conversion to CO2 through respiration. Ultimately, our goal was to link whole-stream ecosystem metabolism, organic carbon spiraling (i.e., how far organic carbon travels before it's taken up and respired by microbes), and carbon export. We received funds to conduct proof of concept data collection, wherein we conducted experiments using whole-stream additions of isotopically labeled DOC to partition DOC uptake and respiration by stream microbes through tracing the fate of labeled DOC to CO2. Our DOC-CO2 tracer experiments were supported by measurements comparing organic carbon cycling rates estimated from bottle assays versus whole-stream metabolism as well as assessments of how stream confluences alter network-scale carbon and nutrient cycling. We also integrated published estimates of metabolism and carbon export from streams to compare biological removal of organic carbon and inorganic nitrogen among streams draining different land uses and assess global patterns of stream and river carbon metabolism.

 

We successfully linked stream DOC uptake (as both plant leachate and glucose) with respiration, and generated the first direct evidence for DOC uptake contributing to whole-stream respiration of CO2 while DOC is in transport through streams. We developed a method to analyze 13C-DOC in water samples to trace changes in 13C-DOC as well as 13C-CO2. We also developed a model that partitioned the immediate versus delayed release of labeled 13C-CO2 due to both immediate and delayed respiration of the DOC taken up by microbes in the stream. We found that plant litter leachate was nearly as labile as glucose in terms of how quickly it was taken up in streams. About 20-40% of the DOC added to our study stream was respired to CO2 immediately, while much of the rest was taken up and released in a delayed fashion within ~24 hours of uptake. Glucose had a longer residence time between uptake and respiration compared to plant leachate; leachate uptake was slower than glucose, but a higher fraction of it was respired.

Through the Virginia Tech team's work integrating published rates of organic carbon (OC) metabolism and spiraling with nutrient cycling, we found: (1) OC travels longer distances before being respired in agricultural and urban streams compared to natively-vegetated streams, suggesting that human modifications to landscapes alter stream carbon cycling and transport; OC and nitrate travel similar distances in streams across the US before being taken up by microbes. (2) The presence of stream confluences within a river network may suppress OC metabolism and phosphorus removal, likely due to the physical disturbances within and downstream of confluences; reaches downstream of confluences were often physically and chemically distinct from the upper stream inputs in ways that could not be predicted from only taking measurements in the two stream inputs. (3) Rates of in-stream OC uptake calculated from biological assays consistently underestimate carbon metabolism in streams compared to whole-stream metabolism models; whole-stream process measurements are critical to characterizing land-stream connections and the role of streams in the global carbon cycle.

 

In addition to supporting data collection, research presentations, and peer-reviewed publications, this project directly supported the professional development of two Virginia Tech PhD students, four additional undergraduate researchers at Virginia Tech, and several other early career researchers who assisted with compiling and analyzing existing datasets. All undergraduate researchers funded by this grant continued their professional training in biology or computer science after working on this project. Current positions held by undergraduates who collaborated on this project through Virginia Tech include: MD/PhD student, biological sciences master's students, healthcare professional, and software developer. The PhD students who were supported by this project were both awarded their PhD in 2023; one is currently a postdoctoral researcher and the other is working in an administrative position supporting undergraduate research. Our collaborative project's (Montana, Utah State, and Virginia Tech) engagement with tribal and community college educators during summer fieldwork in Montana allowed for broader training of educators in freshwater science measurement techniques and current topics in stream ecology - Tribal College faculty from the region learned research techniques that can be implemented in classroom situations by joining us in the field and participating in a half day workshop on river metabolism and solute tracer methods.
